Investors will have to put up with Aveva grinding it out. We downgrade our
recommendation to Hold and an undisturbed target price. Yet expect Aveva
shares to fall below this level as the ‘hot’ money moves on to pastures new.

BE

Aveva has announced the termination of the preliminary discussions with
Schneider Electric, and Aveva shares resumed trading this morning. Few
details have come from the companies - but given that the proposed
transaction was similar in nature to last year’s (i.e. new shares issued to
Schneider in exchange for majority ownership and significant cash
payment to Aveva shareholders), we assume the termination was also for
similar reasons. If we had to guess, we would say Schneider lowered the
price between July and December of last year, and then Schneider came
back this week with a similar price thinking it would look relatively better
now that Aveva’s financial forecasts (Bloomberg estimates) have been
reduced by 9-15%.

11:19 am
PM

(Green's on the ropes)

BE

Other suiters? The CEO had commented last month at full year results
that the M&A search could resume and that the company might go back
to old talks. So that was obviously true. Does that mean that all other
suiters are off the table? In the near term, we think a deal is unlikely. It
would be logical to assume that any other potential near-term buyers
would have come forward by now (given that the company has been on
the block since the original Schneider offer last July). However, over the
mid-term, once the O&G market stabilizes, we think industrial
companies remain interested in software-style assets as Industry 4.0, or
the trend of automation and data exchange in manufacturing
technologies, progresses. Indeed, Schneider itself may still be interested,
although presumably would need to alter the price/structure of the deal to
get Aveva interested. We also believe the PLM market itself is seeing
some level of consolidation (note Aspen’s acquisition of Fidelis,
Yokogawa of KBS, Hexagon of NESTIX, Altair of CEDRAT).

BE

Estimates down 10-20% since last year, but likely hitting the bottom.
Our estimates for fiscal 2017 and 2018 revenues adj. PBT of
£207m£56m and £215m/£61m, respectively, are c.10%/20% lower than
our estimates before the first Schneider announcement in July 2015.
Likewise, consensus is down 9% and 15% for revs and PBT since last
year. After negative growth for two years, revenues could stabilize
this year. Fiscal FY16 results (to March) were reported in May, missing
Bloomberg consensus slightly with organic cc revenues down 2% yoy.
However, management pointed to the broadening of its sales efforts to
stave the revenue decline, and we are forecasting flat to slightly positive
revenue growth cc in fiscal 2017.
 Valuation: On the current price of 1613p, Aveva shares would be
trading on 22.5x 2017 calendarized PE, and 15.2x EV/EBITDA. This
compares to CAD software sector of 23.4x and 13.8x and general global
software on 21.3x and 13.6x.

11:29 am
BE

Here's Exane.

BE

Potential bid in context
As with previous UK opportunities, we suspect the rationale for the deal is supported by several aspects;
(1) Valuation. Prior to this announcement Poundland was trading on 7.5x EV/EBIT (undisturbed) for the largest discounter in the UK with over 900 stores (c.600 Poundland and c.300 99p stores).
(2) Discount concept. Steinhoff has indicated their desire to enter the UK discount sector, and to date has opened c.50 Pep&Co clothing/homeware stores and 1 “Guess How Much” variety discount store. Poundland stores can be traded under their current banner with new product ranges, or could be converted into Steinhoff’s other banners.
(3) Household good concepts. Steinhoff currently operates the Bensons and Harveys furniture concepts, they have potential to add c.400 stores in the UK, and some of the Poundland stores may drive greter value from conversion to those formats.
(4) Synergies. There are likely to be back office synergies, and given the low margin at Poundland (c.2.5%) it would not take much in terms of central cost savings to create sufficient synergies to drive a good return from this acquisition.
We note at the current share price Steinhoff would pay c.£500m for the business, small in the context of their own c.EUR 20bn market capitalisation, but consistent with their strategy for M&A fuelled growth.

BE

And Credit Suisse.

11:30 am
BE

Steinhoff has been active of late with its acquisition of Pepkor in 2015
and recent bids for Darty and Argos. Pepkor has two discount ventures
currently in the UK run by Andy Bond – fashion chain Pep & Co launched last
year (c50 stores) and Guess How Much!, a variety discount retailer just
launched in the past few days. This news underscores Steinhoff's interest in
the UK discount space and highlights the attractiveness of discount sector in
Europe in general.

BE

What could Steinhoff offer: Synergies from existing UK business could be
very limited given that Steinhoff's UK portfolio mainly consists of furniture and
household goods retailers - Harveys furniture, Bensons for Beds,
Sleepmasters; but central costs could be taken out (10% of £40m admin
costs is 30bp addition to margin), European expansion could be accelerated
(Spain, and perhaps Poland where Pepkor has 800+ stores), and we would
envisage a much more rapid progression to multi-price, and perhaps some
benefit to Pep from stocking Poundland product. Steinhoff as of end of last
year had cash of €3.1bn on the balance sheet, so it is possible any offer
could be all in cash and highly accretive.

BE

235p price looks reasonable: The key question is what a terminal margin
could be for a business that is facing structural challenges (weak footfall,
deflation, competition etc.). In our model we have EBIT margins going from
2.8% for 16/17 to 3.5% in 2-years. If we assume 3.5% margin on £1.6bn
sales we get 16.4p EPS implying a 14.3x PER on our target price which
sounds like a minimum exit price for this business. Note that Poundland pre-
99p has done 4%+ margin. It is possible there could be other bidders given
the current valuations and given the performance of the business over the
past year, and with CEO Jim McCarthy retiring, the Board might find it hard
not to recommend accepting a bid notably above this price.

11:31 am
BE

And Deutsche.

BE

Today Steinhoff’s discount-oriented ‘General Merchandise’ segment accounts
for 27% sales and 22% of EBIT on a proforma basis, mainly consisting of the
clothing & general merchandise chain Pep, and derivative concepts. However,
only 50 of the 4,400 stores of the division are in the UK since this trial only
launched in autumn 2015. Steinhoff’s main operations in the UK (4% group)
are in its Household Goods division where it operates the Harveys (furniture)
and Bensons (beds) lower-mid market chains. Geographically and by segment
(discount) we believe a bid for 900-store Poundland is consistent with
management’s previously stated ambitions. Notably the company was already
exploring a variety discount trial in the UK and its nascent Mac-Dan chain of 15
stores in France is similar. Poundland’s own strategy has also been converging
somewhat with the trial of a multi-price ‘Poundland&More’ format in UK and
existing multi-price operations: Dealz in Ireland (greater than 50 stores) and Spain (10).

BE

None of which answers why Steinhoff bought, or indeed why Pincus sold, two days before Poundland's numbers.

BE

BE

Want to know what Glencore said?

BE

Deleveraging program continues
Following the additional 9.9% of GlenAgri sold to BCIMC, Glencore has now achieved 3.2bn of the $4-5bn divestment target for 2016. Rail infrastructure,
$
precious metals monetisation and non-core copper assets are all in process which should allow GLEN to achieve this target. The agriculture sales are not
expected to close until Q4 and with stronger commodity prices there is likely to be a modest working capital build suggesting the true progress on deleveraging
will not be visible in the half year results.
Agriculture JV rationale
Glencore had been looking for a partner in Agriculture since the end of 2014 as they expect consolidation to occur in this still fragmented industry (similar to
that which happened in the mining sector in the 2000s). These transactions allow for GLEN to delever the balance sheet but also keep exposure to future
opportunities within the industry. GlenAgri is a physically separate business to the remainder of Glencore ( t's headquarters are in Rotterdam) and the debt will
i
be separate (except for a Viterra bond due 2020) with no recourse to Glencore.
Zinc and copper

With zinc and copper becoming more geologically scarce and concentrates becoming more complex, Glencore's trading business should benefit. Low
inventories on a global basis in both zinc and copper were highlighted as starting to help drive better fundamentals, with TC/RCs also starting to pull back. They
continue to see strong order books in China (no different to any other time).
Zinc restarts require better economics
Glencore is approaching any potential restart of the 500,000 tonnes of closed zinc production as a holistic ecision not just based on LME prices, but also on
d
TC's and premiums and potential impact on marketing revenues. They have not yet done the work on restarting but higher prices will still be required. Each of
the shut mines will see its own decision be made. Supportive for zinc, the ramp ups are expected to be slow as Glencore will need to rehire employees, assess
ground conditions, build stockpiles,etc. The initial shutdown of Iscaycruz in 2009, and subsequent 3 year ramp up was highlighted as likely being indicative of
the outlook for this shut-in production.

11:46 am
BE

Today’s Q1 update suggests that the Jimmy Choo brand is showing resilience in a difficult market. Management is comfortable with FY consensus of £32m PBT, 27% growth yoy driven by strong operating leverage. The shares are down -30% year to date and -20% in the past two weeks which suggests a crisis. Others may be suffering but Choo is not. We leave forecasts and our 135p TP unchanged but see the shares as oversold. We upgrade to BUY.

BE

Huge growth opportunity

Scope for growth in China vs luxury industry which is over stretched. Choo has 10% new space planned globally in 2016.

FY guidance maintained

We are encouraged at this Q1 stage that Choo remains confident of meeting FY forecasts. Our estimates are based on 9% Retail growth and a conservative 3% in Wholesale.

Strong operating leverage

Operating efficiencies and cost control will drive strong margin expansion, we believe. We see 50bps on EBIT margins this year rising to 180bps over three years.

Valuation

Three year EPS CAGR of 20% is at the top of the range for the peer group while the company is at an 18% discount to the sector on a PE basis.

BE

11:53 am
PM

PM

PM

Neil Mellor

11:53 am
PM

BNY

PM

Bunds reached new highs yesterday with the yield on the ten year note falling to -0.035%. Of course, prices have been rising steadily since the 2008 crisis, but the fact that this past month's upward lurch in prices has mirrored the rise in one month, 25 delta risk reversals in EUR/GBP (which now stand at record highs) leaves little doubt as to the present motivation driving demand. Indeed, with the UK's referendum on EU membership drawing ever closer, investors are turning to a familiar range of safe havens and in fact their price action has been reminiscent of early 2015 when the ECB at long last put speculation to bed and launched QE.

PM

The yield on Denmark's 10 year sovereign debt reached lows of 0.225% yesterday with lower levels only ever seen during a two week period spread over the first four months of last year. Denmark is after all a AAA-rate nation that boasts a current account surplus of 6% of GDP and so, the country's currency peg with the EUR is once more under growing pressure amidst rising demand for the krone. Indeed, EUR/DKK is also at one year lows, or near the infrequently visited lower end of the pair's trading range seen since 2005. And in order to keep it there, the Danish central bank was obliged to intervene in the market last month for the first time in three. The bank's rear-guard action to counter the ECB's policy shifts last year saw it implement several rate cuts in succession, which took them to -0.75%. But any notion of normalisation in 2016 - that began with a hike in January to -0.65% - has once more been subjected to delay: should pressure on the peg continue, then the Bank may well opt to reverse January's hike rather than persist with intervention.

11:54 am
PM

Unsurprisingly, Swiss assets have also been subjected to increased demand. The slide in Swiss sovereign yields has outpaced those of Bunds on both a two and ten year basis since the start of the month and the ten year note now offers a record, negative yield of -0.48%. The CHF itself has also moved sharply higher against the EUR and one month risk reversals in EUR/ CHF have fallen to levels not seen since early last year. However, we are ever aware that the CHF is a thorn in the side of the SNB, and the currency is still trading 10% above the previously capped "highly overvalued" level of 1.20 CHF to the EUR. Clearly the franc's vault higher last year has severely complicated the country's fight with deflationary pressure and Switzerland has been trapped in a danger zone ever since. The SNB will be unable to fight a strong tide, but it may well be prepared to make life as difficult as possible for those looking to the CHF as a default option.

PM

Poor swiss

PM

And Japan...

11:55 am
PM

Speaking of making life difficult, the JPY is also in demand but as with the CHF, this is not something that the BoJ or Ministry of Finance will suffer gladly. One month 25 delta risk reversals in USD/JPY have moved sharply lower leaving them near one year lows; and although the current 100bp spread between 2 year US and Japanese sovereign yields is not in itself significant (FX wise), its recent slide (now totalling 15bp) cannot be ignored when it has borne out a 60% correlation with USD/JPY over the past decade. However, as Taro Aso's latest warnings attests, the Japanese Ministry of Finance appears quite prepared to tempt the ire of its US counterparts if it means Abenomic's salvation. As we have argued, would it be reasonable to suppose that Japanese policy makers would willingly handicap their efforts just to soothe political strains?

PM

Also, on the Brexit front

PM

ECB backstop ready in case of Brexit according to sources – senior central bank official noted on Tuesday that "there will be a statement to do whatever it takes to maintain adequate market liquidity". A telephone conference call on Friday 24 is also apparently scheduled to decide a response to the UK vote.

11:55 am
PM

That's a snap from Citi

PM

ECB backstop ready in case of Brexit, according to sources – The European Central Bank (ECB) would publicly pledge to backstop financial markets (most likely through FX swap lines) in tandem with the Bank of England should Britain vote to leave the European Union, according to officials quoted by Reuters. The article quotes a senior central bank official saying that "there will be a statement to do whatever it takes to maintain adequate market liquidity", most likely coming out on June 24 if an early-morning result showed that British voters had chosen to leave the EU. The article also reports that euro area central bank governors have scheduled a telephone conference call on Friday 24 to decide their response to the UK vote. Comment: Note that euro area national central bank governors are holding a non-monetary policy meeting on Wed 22 June and a General Council meeting (including the non-euro area central banks) on Thursday 23 June. This is likely to be the forum, in our view, to discuss contingency plans and to agree on any statement that might be necessary the following day when the ECB might have to underpin investor confidence, aiming to limit market volatility.

11:59 am
BE

Lonmin achieved good cost performance in Q2-16, with unit costs -3% q/q. This is
positive as labour reduction/cost-cutting initiatives start to bear fruit. However, we do
not believe this level of performance is sustainable, especially as production declines
into FY17/18E, and we expect costs to increase 8-10% p.a. (vs company guidance of
flat nominal costs). We expect this to lead to Lonmin being FCF negative in FY19E, even
if prices increase as we expect, and is likely to be a disappointment vs consensus. After
a strong share price performance (+485% from January lows), we think the valuation
looks stretched (2x UBSe NPV), and downgrade the stock to Sell from Neutral.

BE

If prices remain at spot, financial leverage would increase to greater than 3x ND: EBITDA in FY18E, and liquidity would be significantly impaired (from a healthy $474m at Mar-16).
However, in a low price environment, we assume Lonmin would likely rather let its
production fall further than put the balance sheet at risk. Nevertheless, in this scenario,
the equity could de-rate materially, and underperform peers. Lonmin remains the most
vulnerable in our view.

BE

We see a better-than-expected performance in the ZAR PGM basket price as the
biggest risk to our cautious stance on Lonmin. Additionally, upcoming wage
negotiations are likely to generate some headlines, especially given the fluid regulatory
backdrop (see our recent note). Ultimately, we believe wage increases are likely to be
settled at increases of 8-10%, similar to previous agreements, and in line with broader
expectations.

11:59 am
BE

Our PT increases to 140p (from 110p) as we now base our PT on a mix of EV/EBITDA
and NPV (vs NPV previously) bringing Lonmin in line with the rest of the SA PGM sector.
We also initiate on the SA line of Lonmin, with a Sell rating and a ZAR30 PT (same PT
basis). We have updated estimates, reflecting the fluid price environment and likely
changes to production and capex we expect as a result.

Lonmin PLC (LMI:LSE): Last: 170.25, down 5.75 (-3.27%), High: 181.50, Low: 170.19, Volume: 1.09m
